But concerning the , that we were called all those years, the newcomers, the survivors, we got together. We had our groups. We start to play cards, we let a normal life. Tried to lead a normal life. Of course, the past, you cannot forget. And you cannot just let go. It's deep in you're mind and in you're heart. | think of it until the day you die. It will never, never, never leave us for one minute. Those years back, even up until now we have the same organized organizations, which is only by survivors. We have New Years Eve parties. | got involved, years later, | got involved in the ZOA. We had a group, then we moved to, this was many years later, to Pelham Parkway. | got involved there. | was President of the , It's a Chapter from the ZOA. District 20. And we made like a Ladies Auxiliary, it's a chapter of it and | was President for ten years. | worked very hard, of course no pay. And we raised money for Israel. Our lives was quite normal. | still did not talk about what | went through to the kids. Until my grandchildren started to grow up and understand what means, they start to learn in school and ask questions, then | started to talk about it. But our life here was pretty good, | can't complain really. | never complained and my husband worked very hard. | never worked. To me the kids were my first priority. And | took care of the kids, | didn't trust any babysitters. For five years | never saw a movie in this country. Any place | went there were the kids and the kids and the kids. Later on, when they got a little older, | put my emphasis on education. | tried my best to push my kids through schools. If they were weak, to, never had a babysitter in their lives. To, how you call it, someone to help my kids with education because | wasn't knowledgeable enough in this country to learn English. | never went to school here. Whatever | learned, whatever | know in writing or reading, is only from reading. | read a lot in those years, an awful lot. And this is what | tried to push on my kids. Send them to Hebrew school, send them to, | led a pretty normal, Jewish life. Going to even when they, when my husband went to work | took both kids, schlepped them to school. Of course, the holidays, | was very close with his family. He had a, then two or two-and-a-half years later, after we came to this country, | think two-and-a-half or three-and-a-half years, we brought his mother, his sister with her family, a husband and two kids, to this country. And | considered myself extremely blessed and very lucky to be into a family. Because | didn't have anybody from my mother's side or my, | had my father's two sisters and some cousins here, but they were very good, but survivors? | was the only one. There was another sister of my mother with five kids. They all got killed in Lack-ma (ph). In my town where | was born, the name of it is Lack-ma (ph). They all got killed. So | considered myself very blessed and very fortunate to go into a full family. They all came from Russia. My husband lost his father right when the Germans came into their town, they killed him immediately. No, they didn't. They took him into a camp and they burned him, to Belzec. And he got burned, they burned him. But the two brothers and the sister and the mother are very, very close. All these years, they were in business together, we lived in the same area together, more or less. | lived in , the Parkway, they lived on the Concourse and then they moved to Parkway, and then we all moved to Pelham Parkway. And that's where we lived for eight years until | moved in here and | considered myself very lucky to be in a family like this and my life here was quite normal. My husband tried to be in business all their lives, on his life. He worked himself up. Thank God he made a good living, always. Money was no problem. When | had the supermarkets, food, | always had galore. And we went into real estate little by little. And thank God financially we did pretty well for ourselves.

segments.question: What sort of things became important to you based on you're experiences during the war? You said food, for one.
segments.answer: My family. My children. To raise my children, maybe in a liberal way, maybe too much liberal. Maybe too much of liberal. To raise my kids, to give it to them, they shouldn't be hateful. They should love all kinds of people. They should be good people. They should have professions. They should have a profession and God forbid a war comes over or whatever, they should have something to fall on. Because my father, if not this profession where he was a barber, we would never have survived. See, | wanted my kids to have some kind of a profession. Of course, | didn't want them to be a tailor or a carpenter because this is not the Jewish mother's thing for children. What does a Jewish mother want, is her husband? Her children should be a doctor, a lawyer, a teacher, at least a teacher. So | was pushing for teaching for my kids. So both of my kids actually, originally they became teachers. My son was a special education teacher and my daughter, she wanted to be a veterinarian when she was a little girl, but she was raised in the 1960's. She was not really a full fledged hippie, but kind of on the very liberal side. She went to Binghamton, to school, was . And what | said, | was pushing for teaching. Now she became an Anthropology teacher, she's a very bright girl. And she was teaching anthropology for a full year and then she came home and said, "Ma, | don't like this profession. | don't want to be an anthropologist." | said, "What do you want to be?" "I want to be a doctor." | said, "You're crazy. Now, after so many years, so much work you put in being a teacher, now you want to be a..." "I want to be a veterinarian." Well, she's very bright. | was against it. The truth is she took crash courses in Italian. She was short in Bio, she was short in Chemistry, and she went to Italy and she became a doctor veterinarian. And she's practicing now. And she's doing very well. She has her own place and she is a very good veterinarian. My son became a special education teacher. And after a while he didn't like teaching either. He didn't want to be a teacher. And he got hooked up with a friend and somebody else, | guess, and they went into Nutra System Diet Centers. And thank God, God was good to them. He did very well. Very well. He makes a good living. Now the Nutra System is not so well, the Diet Centers, but he makes a living, thank God. He does pretty good. She's also a teacher, his wife. A lovely, lovely Jewish girl, very nice. An angel of a child. And they gave me three beautiful grandchildren. And this is my whole life, | live for them. | lived for them. And | still do. | still do live for the children. This is my whole life. Nothing else matters to me.

segments.question: And you were talking about discussing the stories from the war with you're kids. | mean, did you discuss, did you talk about it with you're husband? Did you talk about it with other people?
segments.answer: With my husband, we talked, yeah. | talked to my husband, also not too much. Also not too much. He never talked at all. But also not too much. | was going on with my daily routines of life. Getting up in the morning, cleaning, see that the kids should go out for fresh air, taking them to schools, baking, being with his family, being with my family. And this was more or less my life, was wrapped around this here. Not too much talking. | started to really open up more when my grandchildren started to ask questions because it was, when my kids went to school they didn't talk too much about the Holocaust. They really didn't. Not in schools. But at home, | couldn't talk. | didn't want to put this pain on them. But only when my grandchildren in Junior High School, | think, started to talk about it. And then they kept on asking questions and | really started to open up to them. And | was sitting with them, they were writing and telling what | told them and | told them what | went through. They do know. | don't Know if they know every, little detail, but most of it. They do, they know what | went through, yes, they do know.

segments.question: How did you talk to your own kids? | mean, you're son was born in one of the DP camps.
segments.answer: . He knew that | am a survivor and | went through Hitler and | lost my mother, my sister, my brother. | survived. And that's how | met his father. He knew that he was born in this DP camp in Fohrenwald, he knew about all those things. Which is not, it's painful and as a child they cannot realize what this means and how much pain his mother went through. And even, | don't know if they know even the loss, if they could feel what | lost. If they could feel my loss and my mother. | was raised without a mother practically. When | needed her the most she wasn't there anymore. And | had to take care of other people all my life, in order to survive. This was in the partisans, even after the war, when my father married my stepmother. She wasn't a good woman and | had to prove myself, to be good and to be, and to do things. | always took care of somebody, all my life I, nobody, except | happen to take care of me, but | always did for people that my life should be easier or to be good or to impress people. They shouldn't hurt me, they shouldn't leave me. The fear of leaving was in me a lot, a lot. Like especially fear with my father of leaving. It was really kind of a, painful to me. Very painful. Even here, being in this country, and he didn't live here. This feeling went away when he died. It's like it was wiped away, like | was relieved. And up until then, until the day he died, just either | was holding on to him . When he died, | was sure that, you know, God took him away and | cannot even explain. | cannot explain the feeling of it. The fear that I'm going to be left alone. But when he died, its like something, a clock in me says well, this is, if he left you and he will never come back and you have to take care of yourself and you're family. This is you're family. You're father is gone, you cannot lay on him anymore. You cannot depend on him anymore. He cannot save you anymore. These fears for some reason, it was, it was a terrible, frightening thing. Maybe if it was just me, maybe other people didn't have this, | don't know. But | had this pain, | had this terrible pain.

segments.question: Before you're father died, what was you're relationship with him? After the war, did you talk to him about that?
segments.answer: Unfortunately, yeah, we talked, | talked to my father, yeah. | was like his life. | was, | am by nature, | was a strong, self-confident person. My father gave it to me. He was the one who inflicted this on me. You are beautiful. You are the smartest. You know how to do this and he gave me the confidence in him, in me. He made me, whatever | am now, he made me. But unfortunately, circumstances after the war ripped us apart. He went to Israel. | went to this country. Then he couldn't come here. And he went to Canada. As soon as he got to Canada, he was, from Israel he traveled to Argentina, he had a sister there. And from there he couldn't come to straight here, but to Canada, through Italy, so he was in Italy. And | was always of course in touch with him, close in touch with him. But really, being together he should see me grow as a woman, grow as a mother, grow as a wife. Having a family that, he never saw it because he wasn't with me. That's bothered me a lot, it still does. , but when it came to , for some reason it didn't work out. So then he lived in Canada, in Montreal. And | use to go there constantly, he use to come to me. He was when my son was born. It's not like you could hold his for my child. It was just the circumstances didn't happen, it just didn't happen. | use to go a lot to Montreal, | open him a barbershop, | didn't have too much money then but | did my best. | opened him up a barbershop to make him happy.
